questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the structure of Mucormycosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta 1, 3D glucan Invasive fungal infections (fungal infection of an otherwise sterile site, such as the bloodstream or deep tissues) are associated with significant morbidity and mortality, particularly in situations where diagnosis and initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy is delayed. The gold standard remains histopathologic examination of biopsy material from affected tissues alongside culture. Routine fungal culture can be helpful, however results may also be confounding. Sensitivity of culture is generally low and is largely dependent on the quality of the specimen submitted. Also, some fungal pathogens require prolonged incubation, which can further delay diagnosis. Because of these limitations, alternative diagnostic assays for detection of IFIs, including both molecular testing and identification of fungal biomarkers, including detection of the pan-fungal biomarker 1-3 beta-d-glucan or BDG are very useful for timely detection. Beta 1, 3 glycan is a component of the cell wall of most of the fungi except in some organisms (organisms lack BDG or produce it in low amounts) Mucormycosis / Zygomycetes Cryptococcus Blastomycosis Results from this assay need to be used in conjunction with the other diagnostic procedures previously mentioned, including imaging studies, culture and histopathologic examination of biopsy material as available.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C, D: Chitin, ergosterol and mannose are present as part of fungal components in Mucorales.

options.label: A
options.text: Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for all trematodes

options.label: B
options.text: Fasciola hepatica infection occurs through contaminated water plants

options.label: D
options.text: Fasciola buski resides in intrahepatic radicles

questions.correct_answer: B. Fasciola hepatica infection occurs through contaminated water plants
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fasciola hepatica infection occurs through contaminated water plants Option B: Fasciola hepatica is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae encysted on raw aquatic vegetation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option. A. Praziquantel is the DOC for all trematodes. Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for Fascioliasis. Option. C. Schistosoma haematobium is diecious (sexes are separate), as Trematodes are hermaphrodite (monoecious) except schistosomes. Option. D. F. buski resides in the GI tract (small intestine), not intrahepatic radicals.

Solution:

Toxoplasma gondii Option D: The given image shows the life cycle of toxoplasma gondii Life cycle of T. gondi Definitive host – Cats (enteric cycle) Intermediate hosts – humans, mice, rats etc. (exo enteric cycle) Both asexual reproduction and sexual reproduction occurs within the mucosal epithelium of the small intestine of cats Tachyzoites and tissue cyst represents stages of asexual reproduction Oocysts are formed by sexual reproduction In definitive hosts – all three forms Tachyzoites, tissue cysts and Oocysts occur. In intermediate host only Tachyzoites and tissue cysts are present Asexual stage Oocysts (containing sporozoites) or tissue cysts (containing bradyzoites) are ingested by intermediate hosts 🡪 Bradyzoites and sporozoites are released in the intestinal epithelium to form Tachyzoites 🡪Divides and replicates in all the mammalian cells except RBCs🡪 Tissue cysts are formed Sexual stage – Occurs in cat (definitive host) and Oocysts are formed which after sporulation are excreted

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option. A. Praziquantel is the DOC for all trematodes. Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for Fascioliasis. Option. C. Schistosoma haematobium is diecious (sexes are separate), as Trematodes are hermaphrodite (monoecious) except schistosomes. Option. D. F. buski resides in the GI tract (small intestine), not intrahepatic radicals.

questions.text: A man with FUO presented to the hospital. He travels frequently around the world for his job. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

rK39 for leishmaniasis Option A: The history of frequent travel and fever of unknown origin suggests infectious cause. The image of bone marrow biopsy shows Donovan bodies (LD bodies) indicating leishmaniasis. It can be diagnosed by rK39 antigen test In humans, the disease present in 4 different forms Visceral leishmaniasis / kala azar Cutaneous leishmaniasis Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, D: These are incorrect as the given picture shows LD bodies.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HTLV Option D: Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, C: Integration of the viral genome into the host cell thereby leading to the formation of provirus is a common mechanism of viral microbial carcinogenesis directly, especially in DNA viruses.

questions.text: A patient presents with submandibular region swelling after a few days of dental procedure. Yellow granules are present in the discharge. Gram stain is shown in the image. What is the pathogen responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Actinomyces israelii Option B: The given clinical features and the image shows gram positive, filamentous rod suggests diagnosis of Actinomyces israelii.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Gram stain shows gram positive bacilli in chains. Option C: Gram stain shows Budding yeast cells. Option D: Gram stain shows gram positive cocci in clusters.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parvovirus Option D: Parvovirus is a non-enveloped, single stranded DNA virus. Aplastic crisis in a child with hereditary spherocytosis is most likely due to infection of Parvovirus. This aplastic crisis is due to the transient arrest of erythropoiesis where the Parvovirus infects and kills red cell precursors. Patient with aplastic crisis appears ill with fever, malaise and pale with tachycardia and tachypnoea due to profound anemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, C: These are incorrect as option A is correct.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected and processed for examination. Identify the level at which parasite ova will be seen when viewed under microscope.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D Option D: The image shows formaline ether sedimentation technique for stool concentration. sediment at the bottom (D) part of the tube contains the eggs and cysts of parasites. It is used for samples in which the concentration of parasite ova is scanty. Ether absorbs the fecal debris and floats. Formalin fixes and preserves the specimen.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Top layer consists of ether Option B: Second layer is formed by plug of debris Option C: Third layer is a clear layer of formalin.

questions.text: A 27 years old male presented with fever, dyspnoea, palpitations and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is likely the Diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute angle branching septate hyphae- Aspergillus

options.label: C
options.text: Right angled branching septate hyphae – Fusarium

options.label: D
options.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees – mucormycosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Acute angle branching septate hyphae- Aspergillus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute angle branching septate hyphae- Aspergillus Option A: The image shows fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species with non-pigmented, narrow, septate hyphae branching at acute angle Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised individuals. Rhinocerebral Aspergillus infection in immunocompromised individuals resembles that caused by mucormycosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B – Rhizopus shows broad aseptate hyphae. Option C – Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. Microscopy shows hyaline septate hyphae with dichotomous branching like Aspergillosis. Culture is necessary for differentiation and to confirm the isolate. Option D – Mucormycosis shows broad ribbon-like non septate hyphae of variable width (6 to 50 micro m) with frequent right-angled branching.

questions.text: An emergency surgery was conducted for intestinal obstruction and segment of the intestine resected with worms embedded in mucosa as shown in the image. Which of the following is correct regarding the pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal distal end bulb Option D: T he given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides. The distal end of the esophagus is globular known as esophageal bulb. Ascaris is the most common human helminths and distributed worldwide. Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) The adult worms are large cylindrical worms with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A – 14 – 15 proglottids are seen in tape worms Option B – Flame cells are seen in excretory system of trematodes Option C – Hooks and/or suckers are seen in cestodes or trematodes.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy and appears as shown below. Which of the following features/tests will be characteristic of the organism?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin

options.label: B
options.text: Ferment glucose and maltose but not inulin

options.label: C
options.text: Oxidase and catalase are positive and do not ferment maltose or glucose.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Catalase negative, optochin sensitive Option D: The given clinical features of meningitis and the slide showing gram negative diplococci suggests streptococcus pneumonia. It is catalase negative and optochin sensitive and ferments inulin. Pneumonia are the commensals in upper respiratory tract and can cause pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis media, bronchitis, bacteraemia, meningitis, peritonitis and other infectious processes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, C: These are incorrect as it is catalase negative and optochin sensitive and ferments inulin.

Table:

#MANTRA STAPHYLOCOCCI STREPTOCOCCI 1. They are arranged in grape like clusters. 2. They may be coagulase positive or negtive. 3. Infection cause by them is associated with purulent discharge. 4. They produces golden yellow coloured pigment in culture media. 5. No diseases are associated with them related to molecular mimicry. 1. They are arranged in chain. 2.They are always coagulase negative. 3. Infection caused by them is associated with serous discharge. (because of streptodornase) 4. They don't produce any pigment in the culture media. 5. Infection by Lancefield Group A streptococcus is associated with molecular mimicry,causing Rheumatic fever and Glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is involved in delayed hypersensitivity? Cytotoxic T cells Macrophages Neutrophil Dendritic cell Select the correct answer from given options
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A, B

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A & B: Cytotoxic T cells and macrophages are involved in delayed/type 4 hypersensitivity. Option C & D: T cells and macrophages are main cells responsible for DTH. Cell mediated hypersensitivity (type IV) Mechanism Activated T lymphocytes Release of cytokines, inflammation and macrophage activation T cell mediated cytotoxicity Examples – Contact dermatitis, Multiple sclerosis. Tuberculin reaction, Lepromin test etc.

questions.text: A 32 years old construction worker came to the hospital with complaints of cough, fever and hemoptysis. The sputum smear examination done shows the following image. What is the sequence of staining?

options.label: B
options.text: Carbol fuschin – acid alcohol - Methylene blue

options.label: C
options.text: Methylene blue – malachite green – acetic acid – water

questions.correct_answer: B. Carbol fuschin – acid alcohol - Methylene blue
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbol fuschin – acid alcohol - Methylene blue Option B: The given clinical features and the image suggests diagnosis of tuberculosis. The image shows ZN staining. Tuberculous bacilli appears bright red against blue background. Steps in ZN staining are Place the sample on the slide and evenly spread by rotational movements Air dry and fix it by passing over flame Apply Carbol fuschin and heat to fix it Wash with water to remove excess stain Decolorize with alcohol Apply Methylene blue/malachite green stain Wash with water and remove excess stain Visualize under microscope

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C, D: These are incorrect and correct steps are mention in option B.

questions.text: A 45 years old man developed generalized muscle spasm and arching backwards as shown in the image. He had sustained a puncture wound on his leg a few days back. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for this abnormal posturing?

options.label: A
options.text: Presynaptic inhibition of Acetyl choline receptors

options.label: B
options.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

options.label: C
options.text: Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Acetyl choline release

questions.correct_answer: B. Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: The image shows backward bending (opisthotonus) position of the person and the history of puncture wound few days back suggests diagnosis of tetanus. Tetanospasmin is the toxin responsible for this. It acts by causing presynaptic inhibition of GABA and Glycine release. The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 4 – 5 days up to 3 weeks. Muscle spasms usually involve the area of injury first and then muscles of jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles involved, you resulting in tonic spasms.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Presynaptic inhibition of Acetyl choline release is seen in Botulinum poisoning. Option C: Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Acetyl choline release is seen in Botulinum poisoning. Option D: Postsynaptic inhibition is seen in Strychnine poisoning.
